STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 6, 2025
Jaclyn Carroffino
Jackson County DHHS
301 E LOUIS GLICK HWY,
JACKSON, MI, 49201-1535
RE: License#: CP380201203
Dear Jaclyn Carroffino:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 1/2/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

children in foster home, Supervise

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of Three open foster home records reviewed contained a renewal
recommendation not made at least 15 days prior to license expiration. Report
dated 6/12/24 for license expiring 6/16/24.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following
in the child's record before a change of
placement occurs:
• (f) Notification to the parents, referral
source, lawyer guardian ad litem, and
courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.

One of Eight open files of youth in foster care placements reviewed did not
contain documentation of notifications to GAL, court, or parent of youth's
placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 1/5/2024, CAP Approved 2/6/24
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following
in the child's record before a change of
placement occurs:
• (g) Information about the child was
shared with the new placement,
consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
Two of Eight open files of youth in foster care placements reviewed did not
contain documentation that all required information was provided to new
caregiver following a placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 1/5/2024, CAP Approved 2/6/24
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following
in the child's record before a change of
placement occurs:
• (h) The child's new location and address.
Two of Eight open files of youth in foster care placements reviewed did not
contain notification in writing to current foster parent within 14 days of a
placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 1/5/2024, CAP Approved 2/6/24
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy

• (2) An agency shall maintain a file
documentation from the medical or dental
provider of all medical and dental care received
by a foster child.
One of Ten (8FC & 2IL) open youth files reviewed did not contain documentation
from a dental appointment entered into the case record.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 1/5/2024, CAP Approved 2/6/24
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (6) Service plans must be signed by the social
services worker and the social services
supervisor.
One of Ten (8FC & 2IL) open youth files reviewed did not contain worker &
supervisor signatures on one case service plan/PATP.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 1/5/2024, CAP Approved 2/6/24
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of Two open files of youth living independently did not contain
documentation of the youth being given the agency IL program statement prior to
IL entry.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 1/5/2024, CAP Approved 2/6/24
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
• (3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the agency's
policies and procedures required by this rule.

One of Two open files of youth living independently did not contain
documentation of the youth being given agency IL policies and procedures prior
to IL placement.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
• (2) An agency shall provide the following
minimum supervision:
• (a) Face-to-face contact between the
social service worker and the youth in
independent living at least once each
month at a youth's place of residence.
Two of Two open files of youth living independently did not contain
documentation of face to face visits with the youth in the IL placement every
month. One file was missing one visit while the other file did not have any visits
with the youth documented as the youth was living out of state and all visits were
being conducted virtually.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 1/5/2024, CAP Approved 2/6/24
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of Two open files of youth living independently did not contain all required IL
agreements signed by the youth.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 12/15/2022, CAP Approved 1/13/23
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was not requested or required.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Review agency policy as it relates to closed adoption files to ensure the files
are disseminated to central records within the policy required timeframes.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The one
CAP submitted by the agency was in response to the 1/5/2024 interim licensing
inspection report. The CAP was approved 2/6/2024 and addressed twelve (4 rule
& 8 policy) citations. The CAP was successful in four of the areas addressed
through the CAP as evidenced by those areas not being found in violation this
year. Of the remaining eight areas addressed in that CAP, two were not reviewed
this year as they were policy violations and five were repeated this year, requiring
additional assessment and corrective action planning. In addition, four violations
were established this year that were not found in the last inspection; however, one
of those four was addressed through a 1/13/2023 CAP following the 12/15/2022
renewal licensing inspection report. It should be noted that four of the violations
established this year are rule subsection violations that were also cited last year;
however, those subsections were combined into one violation last year giving the
appearance of an increase in violations this year.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment indicated Quality Improvement activities
were implemented throughout the year resulting in improvements in required visits
and initial medical/dental appointments. The Chief Administrator identified
allocation changes resulting in a loss of staffing as well as numerous staff on
medical leave as a barrier to compliance. She indicated caseloads have increased
which has resulted in less time providing social work to families. The previous
year's corrective action plan has had some positive impact related to
medical/dental appointments, supervisor involvement in tracking timeliness, and
initiatives impacting key performance indicators. There have also been negative
impacts from the CAP including overwhelming email reminders, calendar invites,
and micromanagement.
Financial Overview
N/A

Staff Interviews
Staff members interviewed reported a positive work environment with a lot of
support from co-workers and management. The change in allocations as well as
staff member medical leave has increased caseloads; however, staff interviewed
reported being in compliance with caseload size and finding their caseloads
manageable with the assistance of co-workers and supervisors. Staff indicated the
previous CAP implementation such as reminders and spreadsheets have helped
keep them on track with requirements and timeframes. No concerns were noted
by any staff other than one who stated an increase in providing data for BSC
tracking purposes can be time consuming.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency office appears to have adequate space and equipment to provide for
the delivery of foster care, foster home certification, and independent living
services. Paper files and physical CHRI are stored securely as required,
preventing unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: Smoke detectors needed in basement and outside of youth's bedroom.
Caregiver needs lockbox for medications.
Resolution: Medication lock box and 2 smoke detectors provided to caregiver
12/4/2024. Photo evidence of medications in lockbox and installed smoke detectors
provided 12/6/24.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
January 2, 2025
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 6, 2025
